Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Towards Effective and Efficient Sensing-Motion Co-Design of Swarming Cyber-Physical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project focuses on swarming cyber-physical systems (swarming CPS) consisting of a collection of mobile networked agents, each of which has sensing, computing, communication, and locomotion capabilities, and that have a wide range of civilian and military applications. Different from conventional static CPS, swarming CPS rely on mobile computing entities, e.g., robots, which collaboratively interact with phenomena of interest at different physical locations. This unique feature calls for novel sensing-motion co-design solutions to accomplish a variety of increasingly complex missions. Towards this, the overall research objective of this project is to establish and demonstrate a generic motion-sensing co-design procedure that will significantly reduce the complexity of the mission design for swarming CPS, and greatly facilitate the development of effective, efficient and adaptive control and sensing strategies under various environment uncertainties. This project aims to offer comprehensive scientific understanding of the dynamic nature of swarming CPS, contribute to generic engineering principles for designing collaborative control and sensing algorithms, and advance the enabling technologies of practically applying CPS in the challenging environment. The research solutions of this project aim to bring significant advance in the environmental sustainability, homeland security, and human well-being. The project provides unique interdisciplinary training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students through both research work and related courses that the PIs will develop and offer.

The project significantly advances the state of the art in cooperative control and sensing and provide an enabling technology for swarming CPS through highly interrelated thrusts: (1) a generic sensing and motion co-design procedure, which reveals the fundamental interplay between the sensing dynamics and motion dynamics of swarming CPS, will be proposed to facilitate the development of effective and efficient control and sensing strategies; (2) by following such co-design procedure, provable correct, computation efficient, and communication light control and sensing strategies will be developed for swarming CPS with constrained resources to accomplish specific missions, e.g., locating pollutants, in an unknown field, while navigating through uncertain spaces; (3) to provide an enabling mobile platform to verify the proposed strategies, innovative small, highly 3D maneuverable, noiseless, energy-efficient, and robust robotic fish fully actuated by smart material will be designed to meet the maneuvering requirements of the proposed algorithms; (4) novel Magnetic Induction (MI)-based underwater communication and localization solutions will be developed, which allows robotic fish to timely and reliably exchange messages, while simultaneously providing accurate inter-fish localization in the harsh 3D underwater environment; and (5) the proposed sensing-motion co-design strategies will be verified and demonstrated using a school of wirelessly interconnected robotic fish in both lab-based experiments and field experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focuses on swarming cyber-physical systems (swarming CPS) consisting of a collection of mobile networked agents, each of which has sensing, computing, communication, and locomotion capabilities, and that have a wide range of civilian and military applications. Different from conventional static CPS, swarming CPS rely on mobile computing entities, e.g., robots, which collaboratively interact with phenomena of interest at different physical locations. This unique feature calls for novel sensing-motion co-design solutions to accomplish a variety of increasingly complex missions.

Intellectual merit.

We proposed a sensing and motion co-design procedure that reveals the fundamental interplay between the sensing dynamics and motion dynamics of swarming CPS. The procedure, which decouples the formation shape dynamics and translational motion dynamics of the entire swarm, significantly reduces the complexity of mission design for swarming CPS and facilitates the development of effective, efficient, and adaptive control and sensing strategies under various environment uncertainties.

By following the design principles provided by the co-design procedure, we designed provably correct, computation efficient, and communication light control and sensing strategies for swarming mobile agents with constrained resources to accomplish the representative missions of swarming CPS, e.g., source seeking, boundary tracking, and environment modeling and mapping. We summarize the main results of the representative missions below.

1. Source seeking. We proposed a distributed speeding-up and slowing-down (SUSD) source-seeking strategy for a mobile sensor network that allows each sensing agent to take instantaneous measurements of the field and collectively move towards the minimum of the filed (the source) without explicitly estimating the field gradient. The SUSD strategy greatly reduces the high cost of computation and communication typically required in swarming robot applications and is robust to both deterministic disturbances and stochastic noise. Extensions to the SJSU strategy have been developed including the use of collaborative nonholonomic robots.

2. Boundary tracking. We proposed a gradient-free modular approach to the tracking of level curves in noisy scalar fields using two nonholonomic mobile robots. The modular approach decouples the problems of formation control and curve tracking, thus allowing the seamless design of the two modules.

3. Environmental modeling and mapping. The state estimation and prediction of spatially distributed fields described by partial differential equations (PDEs) play key roles in services such as chemical containment detection, pollution control, and search and rescue missions. For example, a typical spatially distributed field is the dispersion of gases from a gas source into an ambient environment, which results in a plume. To better monitor the environment and obtain real-time information of the field, we proposed algorithms that deal with simultaneous parameter identification and mapping of spatially distributed fields using mobile sensor networks. Variations of the algorithms dealing with different practical situations were proposed, i.e., we considered the general nonlinear PDE model of the area and fields with obstacles and hazard zones.

In order to validate the proposed algorithms under realistic uncertainties and disturbances, we developed a multi-robot testbed with a controllable diffusion field. We generated a carbon dioxide (CO2) diffusion field in a lab environment and deployed multiple mobile robots equipped with CO2 sensors in the field to conduct the experiments. In order to calibrate and visualize the diffusion field, and evaluate the performance of the multi-robot system, we also constructed a static CO2 sensor network to collect measurements of the field. Experimental results show satisfactory performance and demonstrate the robustness of the algorithm using the multi-robot system.

Broader impact.

The research solutions of this project aim to bring significant advance in environmental sustainability, homeland security, and human well-being. The project provided unique interdisciplinary training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students through both research work and related courses. Two Ph.D. students, two master students, and five undergraduate students were directly involved in the project as research assistants. Though RPI's Engineering Ambassadors (EA) program, EAs who were co-advised by the PI developed an interactive course module "Robotics: can be a motivator for students to learn mathematics" for pre-college students (grades 6-12) and presented the course to hundreds of pre-college students over two years. The course raised the interests of the students in mathematics from early stages, which will further prepare them to excel in STEM-related majors. The research solutions of this project also resulted in a number of journal and peer-reviewed conference publications in the areas of control and robotics.
